awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The mechanisms and evolution of decision-making under conflict: scaling up from molecules to individuals and populations
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This project seeks to answer a fundamental biological question: how do parents decide how much care to provide to their offspring? Parents can go to incredible lengths to provide care, yet parents are constantly faced with competing demands on their time. For example, parents must decide how much time to invest in caring for offspring versus defending their nest from intruders or courting new mates. Using stickleback fish, where fathers are the sole care providers, this research explores how parents make decisions over when to care, court mates, or defend their territories - decisions that are profoundly important to a parent’s ability to pass on their genes to the next generation. This research will help uncover what happens in the parental brain when these decisions are made and, ultimately, help us understand why some individuals are better at decision-making than others. This project will also provide research opportunities for undergraduates and results will be incorporated into outreach activities at local museums, with a particular focus on broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in science.

This project uses an emerging model system for studying behavioral genomics, the three spined stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus), to study the mechanisms and evolution of parental decisions over care, courtship, and territory defense. First, experimental methods will reveal the behavioral decision-making process within individuals, across individuals, and among populations. Second, molecular techniques will uncover the proximate neural, molecular, and hormonal mechanisms by which parents juggle competing demands. Comparing decision-making within and among individuals, as well as across populations will provide insight into the ecological and evolutionary consequences of parental care. Studying the proximate mechanisms will uncover how the brain manages conflicting demands, as well as provide insight into the mechanistic constraints. Together, results will help explain how vital decisions between competing opportunities to increase fitness are made, and more generally, how patterns of behavior emerge from interactions between genomes, environments, and phenotypes. This project will provide valuable training to the Fellow in behavioral genomics. Additionally, results will be broadly disseminated through conferences and outreach activities, and through the development of educational materials for middle and high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

The capacity to make decisions and prioritize in the face of conflict is a fundamental part of life. For example, foraging animals must balance the need to feed themselves against the risk of predation if they hope to survive. Likewise, territorial animals must balance their efforts attracting mates against the need to defend their territories against rivals if they hope to successfully reproduce. Of particular interest are decisions made by animals over whether to court potential mates or defend their territory against intruders. While these decisions have been well-studied from a behavioral standpoint, we know little about how the mechanisms underlying how the brain responds to multiple, competing demands at the same time. My goal is to uncover these mechanisms to explore a fundamental biological dilemma – how do animals make decisions when faced with multiple demands simultaneously? 

As an NSF fellow, I first investigated how the brain responds to the competing demands of courtship and territorial defense in threespined stickleback. I presented nesting male sticklebacks with a territorial challenge alone, a courtship opportunity alone, a territorial challenge and courtship opportunity simultaneously, and a control. When forced to choose, males compromised courtship in favor of defense, and this was mirrored in the brain. I identified a distinct set of genes recruited in the brains of males when faced with the decision over whether to court or defend, but not in the brains of males doing either action alone, reflecting the unique challenges associated with balancing two things at once. 

Next, I expanded this framework to investigate two other vital decisions: whether to court a female in the presence of a predator, and whether to invest in feeding oneself or providing parental care. In each of these cases, I found that males had to behaviorally compromise one of the two actions: males did not court females in the presence of a predator, and males reduced parental behavior in the presence of a feeding opportunity. I then identified distinct sets of genes involved in these decisions, but found that they were largely non-overlapping across these different experiments, suggesting that the brain responds in different ways to different types of tradeoffs. 

Intellectual Merit

The outcome of decisions made by animals determines whether they can successfully mate, defend their territory, find food, and raise offspring – all of which are profoundly important to survival and reproduction. I compared decision-making within and among individuals faced with competing demands, providing insight into how individuals handle important tradeoffs. I then identified how the brain managed these tradeoffs and related this to variation in decision-making, which can help us understand why some individuals are better at decision-making than others. Finally, I created a framework for understanding how animals manage multiple, competing demands simultaneously. Expanding this framework to other organisms and types of tradeoffs will ultimately help us explain and better predict how vital decisions are made.

Broader Impacts

My research has made broader impacts in four key areas: 1) Promoting teaching, training, and learning. In total, I have mentored three undergraduate students and one vet med student providing training in field and laboratory research, molecular methods, statistical modeling, and interpretation and write-up of results. Two of these students completed independent projects and each presented their work at annual student research symposia. 2) Broadening participation of underrepresented groups. As a research mentor, I have worked with students from diverse backgrounds, including first-generation college students and minority students. One minority student I am mentoring recently completed a six-week field season in Alaska with me where she not only assisted with my work, but successfully completed an independent project on egg cannibalism in stickleback while snorkeling for the first time in frigid Alaskan lakes. She will continue working with me and ultimate turn this work into a distinction project, allowing her to graduate with honors. 3) Public engagement and scientific literacy. I worked with the outreach team at the Institute for Genomic Biology to develop hands-on activities on the neurogenomics of behavior for Genome Day, an afternoon of learning about genomes, genes, DNA, and evolution. We also designed a booth for Science Night to teach students at South Side Elementary School in Champaign about anti-predator behaviors. 2) Broad dissemination of results. Results from my work have been published in Biology Letters and were featured in a news article for the Institute for Genomic Biology. I have also presented my work at the annual meetings of the Animal Behavior Society and the International Society for Behavioral Ecology. In addition, I provided a guest lecture for the Animal Behavior course on theory and the evolution of biological interactions.
